class.doc:
BatchAdmin is the administration interface for Curam Batch Processing. It provides methods for modifying the description of a batch process, adding or removing batch groups and associating batch groups with batch processes.
@author SC

class.name: CacheAdmin

method.name: reloadConfigCache
reloadSecurityCache
reloadFieldLevelSecurityCache
method.doc:
Reload the field level security cache on the client. Cache refreshes are propagated across all active nodes in a cluster (if the application is clustered). Inactive nodes will receive the refresh notification once they become active again. This method will not trigger a reload of the client field level security cache if the server is not running in a J2EE container.
@throws AppException Generic Exception Signature. @throws InformationalException Generic Exception Signature.

method.name: reloadResourceCache
method.doc:
Reload the resource cache on the client. Cache refreshes are propagated across all active nodes in a cluster (if the application is clustered). Inactive nodes will receive the refresh notification once they become active again. This method will not trigger a reload of the client resource cache if the server is not running in a J2EE container.
@throws AppException Generic Exception Signature. @throws InformationalException Generic Exception Signature.

method.name: reloadCodetableCache
removeRuleSetFromCache
removeUserPreferenceFromCache
clearIEGCache
resetCodeTableCacheVersion
method.doc:
When reloading the code table cache in a testing environment, the cache reloads but the version number associated with the cache does not get reset correctly. This method resets the cache version number. This method is provided for development testing ONLY and should not be used by production code.
@throws AppException Generic Exception Signature. @throws InformationalException Generic Exception Signature.

class.doc:
EventDefinitionAdmin is the administration interface for Curam Event Maintenance. It provides the functions for adding, deleting, modifying and display event classes. It also provides the functions for adding, removing and modifying event types and also associating event types with their corresponding event classes.
@author TrM

This class provides an interface for administrating Field Level Security. Field Level Security is the ability to secure particular fields displayed on a client screen from certain users.
@author PJ

class.doc:
LogAdmin is the administration interface for the Curam Authorization and Authentication Logs. These Logs provide information on successful and unsuccessful authentication attempts and unsuccessful authorization attempts. It provides methods for obtaining the log entries between a set of timestamps as well as a count of those entries.
@author DM

class.doc:
SecurityAdmin is the administration interface for Curam Security. It provides methods for changing, deleting, inserting and reading Security roles, groups and identifiers.

A User is assigned a Security Role.
A Security Role maps to a list of Security Groups.
A Security Group maps to a list of Security Identifiers.
A Security Identifier may optionally map to a list of Function Identifiers.

Role -> Group -> Security Identifier [ -> Function Identifier ] @author SC

interface.doc: ReloadCache provides methods to reload the security and code table caches.

method.name: addCodeTable
method.doc: addCodeTable adds a new table, a list of codes descriptions and annotations belonging to that table, and assigns a code to be the default code for that table. codetableItemTabList is a tab-delimited string consisting of triplets of codes, descriptions and annotation.

method.name: deleteCodeTable
method.doc: deleteEntireTable deletes the named table and all items belonging to that table.

method.name: changeTableName
method.doc: changeTableName alters the name of an existing CodeTable.

method.name: listAllTables
method.doc: listAllTables returns a list of all available CodeTable Names, Default Codes and Last Modified dates.

method.name: setTableDefaultCode
method.doc: setTableDefaultCode alters the default code of an existing CodeTable.

method.name: addItem
method.doc: addItem adds a new code, description and annotation to a CodeTable.

method.name: deleteItem
method.doc: deleteItem removes a code and description from a CodeTable.

method.name: addEmptyCodeTable
method.doc: Adds an empty code table header to the CodetableHeader database table.

method.name: parseItemList
method.doc: This method expects a tab delimited string consisting of triplets of codes, descriptions and annotations. No leading or trailing whitespace should be present.

method.name: changeItem
method.doc: Changes both the code and the description

method.name: readCodeTableItemDetails
method.doc: Get the code table item details based on unique key consisting of code, tableName and locale.

method.name: readCodeTableHeaderDetails
method.doc: Gets the code table details including tableName, timeEntered, defaultCode, versionNo

method.name: listCodeTableHierarchies
method.doc: Return the list of codetable hierarchies defined in the system.

method.name: readCodeTableHierarchyDetails
method.doc: Return the description and top-level codetable associated with a hierarchy.

method.name: readChildCodeTable
method.doc: Return the child code table.

method.name: listCodeTablesInHierarchy
method.doc: Return an ordered list of the code tables contained in the specified hierarchy, starting from the top level.

method.name: listChildrenCodes
method.doc: Return a list of children codes for the specified code.

method.name: listUnlinkedCodes
method.doc: Return a list of code table items that have no parent code.

method.name: modifyChildCode
method.doc: Add or remove a link to a child code.

method.name: modifyParentCode
method.doc: Add or remove a link to a parent code.

method.name: listAllItemsOneLocale
method.doc: Return a list of codes contained in a code table for a particular locale.

method.name: readCTIDetailsForLocaleOrLanguage
method.doc:
Get the code table item details based on unique key consisting of code, tableName and locale. If no code table item is
found for the specified locale, then use the language part to find the code table item.

method.name: listChildrenCodesForLocaleAndLanguage
method.doc:
Return a list of children codes for the specified code. If no list is found with the locale passed in, then use the
language part to find a list of children codes.

method.name: listAllItemsForLocaleAndLanguage
method.doc: Return a list of codes contained in a code table for a particular locale and its language part with no duplicates.

method.name: listUnlinkedCodesForLocaleAndLanguage
method.doc: Return a list of code table items that have no parent code for the specified locale and its language part.

method.name: readCTIDetailsWithCommentForLocaleOrLanguage
method.doc:
Get the code table item details based on unique key consisting of code, tableName and locale. If no code table item is
found for the specified locale, then use the language part to find the code table item.

method.name: readCodeTableDataForLocaleOrLanguage
method.doc:
Get the code table item details based on unique key consisting of code, tableName and locale. If no code table item is
found for the specified locale, then use the language part to find the code table item.

method.name: searchByCodeTableName
method.doc: This method searches for all code table records where the table name fully or partially matches the table name passed in.

interface.name: XSLTemplateAdmin

method.name: addTemplate
method.doc: Adds a new template to the database. Returns a key to the new template instance (version '1'). The templateID from this key can be used to access the XSLTemplateInst table if required.

method.name: checkOutTemplate
method.doc: Checks-out a template. This will throw an exception if the specified template does not exist, or if the template is already checked out. If override is true and the template is already checked out, the existing checkout will be cancelled and this new checkout will be accepted. The contents of the selected template instance are returned.

method.name: undoCheckOutTemplate
method.doc: Undoes the latest checkout of a template. If the override field is true, the userID will not be considered, otherwise only the user who checked it out, can undo the checkout.

method.name: checkInTemplate
method.doc: Checks in a template that was checked out. This will fail if the specified template does not exist, or if the specified template is not checked out. Normally, if the specified template is checked out by a different user, this will fail, however if override is true, the user ID will be ignored. The key to the new template instance will be returned.

method.name: getAllTemplates
method.doc: Returns all the details of all the XSLTemplate records

method.name: getTemplateVersions
method.doc:
Returns all the version numbers of a specified template as a list.The list contains versions for a given 'XSLTemplateID.templateID' and 'XSLTemplateID.locale' with country code and without country code.
i.e. If the XSLTemplateID provided includes the country part as locale (i.e. #en_US#) the method return the template versions with this locale and also append the versions without the country part (e.g. #en#) by truncating the country part from the locale. And If the XSLTemplateID provided does not contain the
country part (e.g. 'en'), the items in the template version list returned by the method are repeated twice for a given locale.

method.name: getTemplateDetails
method.doc: Retrieve the Template details for a specific template.

method.name: getTemplateVersionsForSpecifiedTemplateID
method.doc:
Returns all template versions for a specified XSLTemplateID. If provided XSLTemplateID.locale contains country part (i.e. 'en_US') and if at least one record is found with this locale then the method returns only the template versions with this locale. If no records found for specified locale containing country part (i.e. #en_US#) the method returns the template versions without country part (e.g. #en#). Otherwise if provided XSLTemplateID.locale does not contain country part (i.e. #en#) the method returns only the
template versions without the country part (e.g. 'en').

field.name: name
field.doc:
The name of the resource. This is independent of the locale and the file name and provides a logical name for a resource that is valid for all locales. For example, if resources representing the organization logo image are uploaded from the files "images/en_US/logo.png" and "images/fr_CA/logo.png" (perhaps because the text of the organization name appears in the logo and is translated to the appropriate language for each locale), then the resource name "logo" can be used for both resources and the "locale" field can indicate which image is appropriate for each locale.

RS_RESOURCE_NAME -> String

field.name: contentType
field.doc:
The content type (MIME type) for the resource. This identifies how the binary resource content should be interpreted. See the domain definition for more information.

RS_RESOURCE_CONTENT_TYPE -> String

field.name: contentDisposition
field.doc:
The content disposition for the resource. At its most basic, this can be treated as the suggested file name for the resource if it is used as an attachment. This field may be left blank if it is not required, but it is recommended that it be set based on the original file name of the resource. See the domain definition for more information.

RS_RESOURCE_CONTENT_DISPOSITION -> String

field.name: content
field.doc:
The content for the resource. This is binary data. If the resource is a text resource, then the binary data will be interpreted according to the character set encoding defined as a paramter to the value of the "contentType" field, for example, "text/plain; charset=us-ascii". If no encoding is specifed, UTF-8 encoding will be assumed. See the domain definition for more information.

RS_RESOURCE_CONTENT -> curam.util.type.Blob

field.name: internal
field.doc:
Indicates if resource is internal.

RS_RESOURCE_INTERNAL -> boolean

field.name: description
field.doc:
Description of the resource.

RS_RESOURCE_DESCRIPTION -> String

field.name: category
field.doc:
Category of the resource.

RS_RESOURCE_CATEGORY -> CODETABLE_CODE -> INTERMEDIATE_CODETABLE_CODE -> String

field.name: locale
field.doc:
The locale of the resource. Only resources with locales for which the application has been configured, or that act as fall-back locales for the application's locales, will be used. If the locale is empty, the resource may be used as a fallback if a resource for a specific locale cannot be found.

RS_RESOURCE_LOCALE -> CODETABLE_CODE -> String

The name of the resource. This is independent of the locale and the file name and provides a logical name for a resource that is valid for all locales. For example, if resources representing the organization logo image are uploaded from the files "images/en_US/logo.png" and "images/fr_CA/logo.png" (perhaps because the text of the organization name appears in the logo and is translated to the appropriate language for each locale), then the resource name "logo" can be used for both resources and the "locale" field can indicate which image is appropriate for each locale.

field.doc:
The content disposition for the resource. At its most basic, this can be treated as the suggested file name for the resource if it is used as an attachment. field.name: content
field.doc:
The content for this resource. This is binary data. If the resource is a text resource, then the binary data will be interpreted according to the character set encoding defined as a paramter to the value of the "contentType" field, for example, "text/plain; charset=us-ascii". If no encoding is specifed, UTF-8 encoding will be assumed. See the domain definition for more information.

field.name: locale
field.doc:
The locale of the resource. Only resources with locales for which the application has been configured, or that act as fall-back locales for the application's locales, will be used. If the locale is empty, the resource may be used as a fallback if a resource for a specific locale cannot be found. For example, if the resource named "logo" is requested for the "en_US" locale is requested, but no resource with that exact key exists, then the "logo" and "en" should be checked, followed by "logo" and "" (an empty locale) if that cannot be found.

RS_RESOURCE_LOCALE -> CODETABLE_CODE -> String

class.name: Audit

method.name: getXmlStringRepresentation
parseChangedAuditValues
parseChangedAuditValues
compactXML

class.doc:
This class provides a hook for all audit calls. It is not responsible for logging the audit information, it simply delegates these calls to another class which supports the {@link AuditLogInterface AuditLogInterface}. A default implementation is provided by Curam which writes to the database. This can be overridden by setting the {@link curam.util.resources.EnvironmentConstants.Custom#kAuditWriter curam.custom.audit.writer} application property to the class name of the customized implementation.
@author DM

interface.name: AuditLogInterface

method.name: auditMethodCall
auditDataAccessCall

interface.doc:
This interface provides the contract for storing audit information. Customers can use a standard Curam plug-in to audit information or can write their own version of the plug-in which implements this interface. A plug-in is specified by specifying a class name in the {@link curam.util.resources.EnvironmentConstants.Custom#kAuditWriter curam.custom.audit.writer} application property and implementing this interface in that class.
@author DM

class.name: AuditLogInterface.OperationType

method.name: toString
toCompactRepresentation
method.doc:
Obtain a compact character representation of the transaction type. This compact representation is useful for efficient database storage of this field.
@return A single character describing the transaction type. This may be one of C,R,U or D which represent Create, Read, Update and Delete respectively.

method.name: equals
hashCode
method.doc:
Calculate the hash code for this object.
@return The hash code.

field.name: kCreate
field.doc: Create operation type.

field.name: kRead
field.doc: Read operation type.

field.name: kUpdate
field.doc: Update operation type.

field.name: kDelete
field.doc: Delete operation type.

class.doc: An enumerated type describing the Database operations which can cause audit records to be produced.

interface.name: DataAccessHook

method.name: preDataAccess

interface.doc:
This interface provides the contract for pre data access handling. The class that implements this interface is specified in the property {@link curam.util.resources.EnvironmentConstants.Custom#kPreDataAccessHook curam.custom.predataaccess.hook}. If this property is empty no pre data access will occur.
@author FB

class.name: DisabledAudit

method.name: auditMethodCall
auditDataAccessCall

class.doc:
This class can be used to disable audit information and ensure it is not produced. This class should not be invoked directly - it is called by {@link Audit Audit}.
@author DM

interface.name: ExternalOperationHook

method.name: preOperation

interface.doc:
This interface provides the contract for external operation handling. An external operation is an operation callable as a remote, batch, web service or deferred process call. The class that implements this interface is specified in the value of the property {@link curam.util.resources.EnvironmentConstants.Custom#kCustomExternalOperationHook curam.custom.external.operation.hook}. If this property is empty no pre external operation handling will occur. This hook, provided in the Business Interface layer, has access to all the arguments of the BPO call. If an implementation has been specified for `ExternalOperationHook.preOperation` it will be invoked by infrastructure code in the Curam remote interface layer immediately before the implementation code for the BPO operation. If operation auditing for the BPO is switched on, the following 2 events occur:
  • auditing of the operation will be performed first.
  • The operation arguments will then be passed to ExternalOperationHook.preOperation if the hook is configured.

Operation auditing can be switched on in the model or at runtime by using properties. All other information about the operation can be obtained from {@link curam.util.transaction.TransactionInfo TransactionInfo} including:

  • getProgramTimeStamp - the date/time on which the current business function started executing
  • getProgramName - the name of the currently executing business function.
  • getProgramExecutionTime - the execution time of the program (i.e. the difference between the current time and the program time stamp).
  • getProgramUser - Get the user name of the user associated with the current online transaction.
  • getProgramLocale - the locale of the user currently associated with this transaction.

The audit writer as specified in the property {@link curam.util.resources.EnvironmentConstants.Custom#kAuditWriter curam.custom.audit.writer} (or if not set the default curam.util.internal.misc.impl.StandardDatabaseAudit ) which audits database access, operates before any data access during the execution of the BPO operation implementation code. @see curam.util.transaction.TransactionInfo @author FB

interface.name: Cache

method.name: addListener
removeListener
clear
method.doc: Clears all objects from this cache.

method.name: containsKey
containsValue
put
remove
getAll
get
getEntry
method.doc: This method returns the cache entry for the object mapped to key key. This method behaves similar to {@link #get(Object)}, the only difference being that the cache entry is returned rather than just the cached object. @param key the object's key @return the cache entry mapped to key

method.name: load
method.doc: Uses the associated cache loader to load an object for key key. The loading could be done asynchronously. @param key the object's key

method.name: loadAll
method.doc: Uses the associated cache loader to load all objects with keys in keys. The loading could be done asynchronously. @param keys the key set; This value can be null meaning that the registered loaders should load all available objects into the cache.

method.name: peek
registerCacheLoader
method.doc:
Registers a cache loader. More than one cache loader can be registered and during calls to {@link #get(Object)} or {@link #getAll(Set)}, the cache loader calls will be chained until the requested object is loaded.
@param loader the loader to register

method.name: unregisterCacheLoader
getStatistics
resetStatistics
method.doc: Resets the statistics.

method.name: getName
method.doc:
Returns the name of this cache
@return the name of the cache

method.name: getKeyIterator
method.doc:
Returns an iterator over the keys in the cache. Some caches support only a read only iterator that throws {@link java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException} if {@link java.util.Iterator#remove} is invoked.
@return an iterator over the keys in the cache

method.name: registerEvictionApprover
method.doc:
Registers an eviction approver to be able to veto the eviction of items from the cache. More than one eviction approver can be registered. An item is evicted only if none of the registered approvers vetoed the eviction.
@param cea the eviction approver to register

method.name: unregisterEvictionApprover

A cache.
@author DMoraru

interface.name: CacheEvictionApprover

interface.name: CacheGroup

method.name: getCache
method.doc:
This method looks up the cache with the given name. If a cache with name cacheName already exists then this cache will be returned, otherwise a new cache will be created using the default configuration. This newly created cache will be registered before being returned.
All caches defined in the cache group configuration are guarranteed to exist when this method is invoked.
The cache returned by this method should be cached whenever possible as the implementation of this method is likely to be guarded against concurrent access and as such it is not suitable for high frequency invocations. @param cacheName the name of the cache @return the cache with name cacheName

method.name: getCacheNames
method.doc: @return a set containing the names of all registered caches

method.name: getCaches
method.doc: @return all caches under this group

method.name: getName
method.doc: @return the name of this cache group

method.doc: Cache groups require orderly shutdown. Invoke this method before the application shuts down.

method.doc: @return true if this cache invalidation message is serializeable

class.doc:
This class holds the details for a cache invalidation message.
@author DMoraru

interface.name: CacheListener

method.name: onClear
method.doc: Invoked when the cache is cleared.

method.name: onEvict
onPut
onUpdate
onRemove
method.doc:
Invoked when an object is removed from the cache. This method is not invoked when the cache is cleared. See {@link #onClear()}.
@param key the object's key

interface.doc:
Listener for cache events.
The callbacks to these methods are possibly unsynchronized. It is the responsibility of the implementer to handle any potential concurrency issues. @author DMoraru

interface.name: CacheLoader

method.name: init
method.doc: Invoked only once before the cache loader is first needed.

method.name: dispose
method.doc: Invoked only once when the cache loader is no longer needed.

method.name: load
loadAll

class.name: CacheLoaderAdapter

method.name: loadAll
method.doc: The default implementation uses repeat calls to {@link #load(Object)} to load the required data. If {@link Cache#getAll(Set)} or {@link Cache#loadAll(Set)} are invoked and performance is a concern, implement a more efficient way of loading the required data. If keys is null then nothing is done and null is returned. @throws Exception if an error occurred during the load operation @see curam.util.cache.CacheLoader#loadAll(java.util.Set)

class.doc:
An adapter to simplify the development of cache loaders. It provides no operation implementations for {@link #init()} and {@link #dispose()} and {@link #loadAll(Set)} is implemented using repeat calls to {@link #load(Object)}.
@author DMoraru

class.name: CacheManager

method.name: getDefaultCacheGroup
method.doc:
This method returns the default cache group. Caches from this group are global (JVM level) and can be configured to be distributed across a number of JVMs.
@return the default cache group

method.name: getCacheGroupFactory
method.doc:
This method returns the cache group factory. This can be used to create a new group of global, distributed caches outside the control of Curam Cache. If you want to create a cache group managed by this cache manager, use {@link #createCacheGroup(String, InputStream)} instead.
@return the cache group factory

method.name: createCacheGroup
method.doc: Creates a cache group with the given name and using the configuration from the configuration stream. The cache group is also registered with the cache manager. This means that the cache group can be managed via the standard mechanism offered by Curam Cache. @param name the name of the cache group. The name of a cache group must not contain the dot ('.') character otherwise a {@link InvalidCacheGroupName} will be thrown. @param configuration the stream with configuration data for the cache group @return the newly created cache group @throws CacheGroupNameAlreadyExists thrown when a cache group with name name already exists @throws InvalidCacheGroupName thrown when the name of the cache group is not valid

method.name: getCacheGroup
getCacheGroupNames
method.doc:
Returns the names of all registered cache groups.
@return the names of all registered cache groups

method.name: getCacheGroups
method.doc:
Returns all registered cache groups.
@return all registered cache groups

method.name: getThreadLocalCacheGroup
method.doc:
This method returns the cache group for thread local caches. Note that the returned cache group is a thread local variable. Invoking this method twice on different threads will return different cache groups.
@return the cache group for thread local caches

method.name: createThreadLocalCacheGroup
method.doc:
Use this method to create a thread local cache group when you are already in a thread local context. For instance, if you have an instance of class A that is already a thread local and you need a thread local cache, use this method to create one to be used by this instance of class A.
@return a newly created thread local cache group that must only be used in the thread local context of the caller

method.name: shutdown
method.doc:
Curam Cache requires orderly shutdown. This method must be invoked before the application is shutdown. This method invokes {@link CacheGroup#shutdown()} on every registered cache group and it resets the entire caching environment. If Curam Cache is used after this method has been invoked, a new set of empty caches are created.
In an application server environment, the application infrastructure will invoke this method when the application shuts down.

class.doc:
This is the entry point for clients using the caching service.
@author DMoraru

class.name: CacheManagerEjb

method.name: getTransactionLocalCacheGroup
method.doc:
This method returns the cache group for transaction local caches. Invoking this method twice in the context of different transactions will return different cache groups.
@return the cache group for transaction local caches

method.name: createTransactionLocalCacheGroup
method.doc:
Use this method to create a transaction local cache group when you are already in a transaction local context. For instance, if you have an instance of class A that is already a transaction local and you need a transaction local cache, use this method to create one to be used by this instance of class A.
@return a newly created transaction local cache group that must only be used in the thread local context of the caller

method.name: postInvalidationMessage
method.doc:
This method triggers a cache invalidation throughout the entire cluster. When modifying data that affects the content of a cache do not remove or update the cached element directly; instead invoke this method to post an invalidation message. After invoking this method, the cached object should not be accessed for the remainder of the transaction.
@param <K> The type the key of the entry to be invalidated @param msg the cache invalidation message

class.doc:
Handles the mapping of one field within a class to/from an MQSeries string. The MQStructMapper class creates an instance of this class for each field in a struct and calls the encode and decode methods as necessary.

MQFieldMapper is abstract; each of the its subclasses deals with a different fundamental Curam data-type. Developers may also create their own subclasses of MQFieldMapper and associate them with individual struct fields to create their own custom messages.

This class is intended to be used by code produced by the Curam SDEJ generators but can also be used by handcrafted code. @author BD

class.name: MQStructMapper

constructor.name: MQStructMapper
MQStructMapper
constructor.doc:
Constructs an MQSeries converter given the struct type, an array of MQFieldMetadata containing conversion information about each field of the struct, and context information about the struct.

This version will do default conversion on each field of the given type of struct but the structContext information provides for looking up the names of custom field mapper classes for the fields in the struct in the ResourceBundle QueueConnectorFieldMappers.properties . @param type The type of the struct to be converted. @param fieldsMetadata An array MQFieldMetadata for the fields of the struct @param structContext The context in which this struct is being used - that is, class name, operation name and parameter name. For example: "Person.read.key". This is to enable the developer to associate a conversion with a field of a struct in a specific operation. @throws AppRuntimeException {@link INFRASTRUCTURE#RUN_ID_NO_MAPPING_AVAILABLE_FOR_DATATYPE RUN_ID_NO_MAPPING_AVAILABLE_FOR_DATATYPE} - if no mapping is available for the data type of the field. @throws AppRuntimeException {@link INFRASTRUCTURE#RUN_ID_CUSTOM_QUEUE_MAPPER_CLASS_NOT_FOUND RUN_ID_CUSTOM_QUEUE_MAPPER_CLASS_NOT_FOUND} - if the specified mapper class could not be found. @throws AppRuntimeException {@link INFRASTRUCTURE#RUN_ID_EXCEPTION_CREATING_QUEUE_MAPPER_CLASS RUN_ID_EXCEPTION_CREATING_QUEUE_MAPPER_CLASS} - if the specified mapper class could not be instantiated.

method.name: newInstance
encodeStruct
decodeStruct

class.doc:
Provides functionality for mapping struct classes to/from MQ Series messages. Each attribute of the struct is converted to a string (usually fixed-length) and the message consists of all these strings concatenated together.

The infrastructure provides default conversions for all of the Curam fundamental data types E.g. {@link curam.util.type.Date Date} is converted to a string of the form `ddmmyyyy`, but for any field of a message it is possible for the developer to specify a customized conversion class (i.e. a subclass of MQFieldMapper) which can encode/decode the data into/from a string of any format, including variable length fields.

This class is intended to be used by code produced by the Curam SDEJ generators but can also be used by handcrafted code. @author BD

class.doc:
Helper class for audit mappings. There will be zero or one instances of a subclass of this class per application. This abstract class caches references to setter methods in the handcrafted audit mappings class for the application, and defines abstract methods whose implementation will be provided in the generated audit mappings factory class. This mechanism enables meta-data about the fields, such as their name, type and whether they should be excluded from inserts or updates to be conveyed from the input meta-model to the built application.
@author BD

field.name: kNoResultClass
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code which can be passed as a placeholder when no result is required.

field.name: kNoArg1Class
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code which can be passed as a placeholder when no result is required.

field.name: kNoArg2Class
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code which can be passed as a placeholder when no result is required.

field.name: kInsert
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code to indicate the style of operation that is required - in this case a singleton insert using all the attributes.

field.name: kNsInsert
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code to indicate the style of operation that is required - in this case a singleton insert using a subset of the attributes.

field.name: kModify
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code to indicate the style of operation that is required - in this case a singleton modify using all of the attributes.

field.name: kNsModify
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code to indicate the style of operation that is required - in this case a singleton modify using a subset of the attributes.

field.name: kNkModify
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code to indicate the style of operation that is required - in this case modifying some attributes in all of the records.

field.name: kRemove
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code to indicate the style of operation that is required - in this case a singleton remove based on the primary key of the table.

field.name: kNsRemove
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code to indicate the style of operation that is required - in this case removing a set of records based on a supplied key.

field.name: kNkRemove
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code to indicate the style of operation that is required - in this case removing all the records.

field.name: kRead
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code to indicate the style of operation that is required - in this case a singleton read of all of the attributes based on the primary key of the table.

field.name: kNsRead
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code to indicate the style of operation that is required - in this case a singleton read of a subset of the attributes based on the primary key of the table.

field.name: kNkRead
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code to indicate the style of operation that is required - in this case a singleton read of a subset of the attributes based on a specified key.

field.name: kReadmulti
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code to indicate the style of operation that is required - in this case a read of all the attributes of multiple records based on a specified key.

field.name: kNsReadmulti
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code to indicate the style of operation that is required - in this case a read of some of the attributes of multiple records based on a specified key.

field.name: kNkReadmulti
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code to indicate the style of operation that is required - in this case a read of a subset of the attributes of multiple records based on a specified key.

field.name: kNsMulti
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code to indicate the style of operation that is required - in this case a read of a subset of the attributes of multiple records based on a specified key. This supports more complex selection criteria than an nkreadmulti.

field.name: kNs
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code.

field.name: kBatchInsert
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code to indicate the style of operation that is required - in this case a `batchinsert`.

field.name: kBatchModify
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code to indicate the style of operation that is required - in this case a `batchmodify`.

field.name: kUseLastUpdatedField
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code to indicate that the last updated field should be modified to be the current timestamp. To indicate that the last updated field should not be modified the negation of this class is used (i.e. !kUseLastUpdatedField).

field.name: kUseOptimisticLocking
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code to indicate that optimistic locking should be performed. To indicate that optimistic locking should not be performed the negation of this class is used (i.e. !kUseOptimisticLocking).

field.name: kPerformAuditing
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code to indicate that auditing should be performed. To indicate that auditing should not be performed the negation of this class is used (i.e. !kPerformAuditing).

field.name: kNoOrderClause
field.doc: Constant used in the generated data access code to indicate that an ORDER BY clause should not be associated with the data access operation that is being performed. This is typically specified when the operation also involves a forUpdate specifier as in these cases not all databases can support the ORDER BY clause.

field.name: kNoWhereClause
field.doc: Constant for data access argument - need to consider in more detail.

class.name: DynamicDataAccess

method.name: executeNs
executeNsMulti
method.doc: Executes a SQL statement which will have multiple results. The SQL statement result is returned as a {@link CuramValueList} populated with the results of the dynamic data access SQL as a list of details objects, the type of which are specified as an input parameter. There is no validation of the SQL before execution. The SQL should take the same form as handcrafted SQL in the model. For example: SELECT attribute_one, attribute_two INTO :attribute_one,:attribute_two FROM DynamicSQLTestEnt WHERE attribute_one=:attribute_one; The method requires the type of the objects contained in the list to be defined. The class of the argument that will be passed to make up the SQL statement should also be defined, along with a boolean indicator detailing if auditing should be performed for the SQL statement, and the handcrafted SQL string. {@link DynamicDataAccess#executeNs(Class, Object, boolean, String)} should be used to execute a SQL statement with a singleton result. @param Details Struct Type @param dtlsClass The type of the objects to be contained in the returned list. @param key The class of the argument that will be passed to make up the dynamicSQL statement. null should be passed in if a key is not to be used. @param performAuditing Whether the database updates done by this operation should be recorded on an audit trail. @param dynamicSQL A valid SQL statement to be executed against the database. @return The {@link CuramValueList} populated with the results of the dynamic data access SQL as a list of details objects, the type of which are specified as an input parameter. The list contains all the entries and not only the curam.db.readmultimax number of records. If the readmulti maximum is reached then a readmulti-max message gets logged. @throws AppException If the provided dynamicSQL is invalid. @throws InformationalException Generic exception signature.

method.name: executeNsMulti
method.doc: Executes a SQL statement which will have multiple results and the results is dependent on the specified boolean requireInformational value. The SQL statement result is returned as a {@link CuramValueList} populated with the results of the dynamic data access SQL as a list of details objects, the type of which are specified as an input parameter. There is no validation of the SQL before execution. The SQL should take the same form as handcrafted SQL in the model. For example: SELECT attribute_one, attribute_two INTO :attribute_one,:attribute_two FROM DynamicSQLTestEnt WHERE attribute_one=:attribute_one; The method requires the type of the objects contained in the list to be defined. The class of the argument that will be passed to make up the SQL statement should also be defined, along with boolean indicators detailing if auditing should be performed for the SQL statement and whether an informational is required if readmulti maximum is reached also the handcrafted SQL string. {@link DynamicDataAccess#executeNs(Class, Object, boolean, String)} should be used to execute a SQL statement with a singleton result. @param Details Struct Type @param dtlsClass The type of the objects to be contained in the returned list. @param key The class of the argument that will be passed to make up the dynamicSQL statement. null should be passed in if a key is not to be used. @param performAuditing Whether the database updates done by this operation should be recorded on an audit trail. @param requireInformational Indicator as to whether an informational is required when the readmulti maximum is reached. If the requireInformational is set false and readmulti maximum is reached then a readmulti-max message gets logged and all entries are returned to the user. If the requireInformational is set to true and readmulti maximum is reached then an InformationalMessage can be added to the current transactions Informational-Manager, for handling in the Application's Facade layer. In this case only the specified readmulti-max number of entries will be returned to the user. @param dynamicSQL A valid SQL statement to be executed against the database. @return The {@link CuramValueList} populated with the results of the dynamic data access SQL as a list of details objects, the type of which are specified as an input parameter. The size of the list depends on the specified requireInformational indicator and the curam.db.readmultimax settings. @throws AppException If the provided dynamicSQL is invalid. @throws InformationalException Generic exception signature.

method.name: executeNsMulti
method.doc: Executes a SQL statement which will have multiple results and the results is dependent on the specified boolean requireInformational and readMultiMax value. The SQL statement result is returned as a {@link CuramValueList} populated with the results of the dynamic data access SQL as a list of details objects, the type of which are specified as an input parameter. There is no validation of the SQL before execution. The SQL should take the same form as handcrafted SQL in the model. For example: SELECT attribute_one, attribute_two INTO :attribute_one,:attribute_two FROM DynamicSQLTestEnt WHERE attribute_one=:attribute_one; The method requires the type of the objects contained in the list to be defined. The class of the argument that will be passed to make up the SQL statement should also be defined, along with boolean indicators detailing if auditing should be performed for the SQL statement and whether an informational is required if readmulti maximum is reached, the maximum number of records to be returned by this readmulti operation also the handcrafted SQL string. {@link DynamicDataAccess#executeNs(Class, Object, boolean, String)} should be used to execute a SQL statement with a singleton result. @param Details Struct Type @param dtlsClass The type of the objects to be contained in the returned list. @param key The class of the argument that will be passed to make up the dynamicSQL statement. null should be passed in if a key is not to be used. @param performAuditing Whether the database updates done by this operation should be recorded on an audit trail. @param requireInformational Indicator as to whether an informational is required when the readmulti maximum is reached. If the requireInformational is set false and readmulti maximum is reached then a readmulti-max message gets logged and all entries are returned to the user. If the requireInformational is set to true and readmulti maximum is reached then an InformationalMessage can be added to the current transactions Informational-Manager, for handling in the Application's Facade layer. In this case only the specified readmulti-max number of entries will be returned to the user. @param readMultiMax The maximum number of records to be returned by this readmulti operation. @param dynamicSQL A valid SQL statement to be executed against the database. @return The {@link CuramValueList} populated with the results of the dynamic data access SQL as a list of details objects, the type of which are specified as an input parameter. The size of the list depends on the specified requireInformational indicator and readMultiMax settings. @throws AppException If the provided dynamicSQL is invalid. @throws InformationalException Generic exception signature.

method.name: validateNsMulti
method.doc: Validates an SQL query statement via execution and rollback allowing for multiple results that are dependent on the specified requireInformational boolean and readMultiMax value. The SQL statement result is returned as a {@link CuramValueList} populated with the results of the dynamic data access SQL as a list of details objects, the type of which are specified as an input parameter. This method does not commit any changes on to the database. The SQL should take the same form as handcrafted SQL in the model. For example: SELECT attribute_one, attribute_two INTO :attribute_one,:attribute_two FROM DynamicSQLTestEnt WHERE attribute_one=:attribute_one; The method requires the type of the objects contained in the list to be defined. The class of the argument that will be passed to make up the SQL statement should also be defined, along with a boolean indicator detailing if auditing should be performed for the SQL statement, and the handcrafted SQL string. @param Details Struct Type @param dtlsClass The type of the objects to be contained in the returned list. @param key The class of the argument that will be passed to make up the dynamicSQL statement. null should be passed in if a key is not to be used. @param performAuditing Whether the database updates done by this operation should be recorded on an audit trail. @param requireInformational Indicator as to whether an informational is required when the readmulti maximum is reached. If the requireInformational is set false and readmulti maximum is reached then a readmulti-max message gets logged and all entries are returned to the user. If the requireInformational is set to true and readmulti maximum is reached then an InformationalMessage can be added to the current transactions Informational-Manager, for handling in the Application's Facade layer. In this case only the specified readmulti-max number of entries will be returned to the user. @param readMultiMax The maximum number of records to be returned by this readmulti operation. @param dynamicSQL A valid SQL statement to be executed against the database. @return The {@link CuramValueList} populated with the results of the dynamic data access SQL as a list of details objects, the type of which are specified as an input parameter. The size of the list depends on the specified requireInformational indicator and readMultiMax settings. @throws AppException If the provided dynamicSQL is not syntactically correct. @throws InformationalException Generic exception signature. @throws OtherDatabaseException If the provided dynamicSQL throws any database exception.

method.name: validateNsMulti
method.doc: Validates an SQL query statement via execution and rollback allowing for multiple results. The SQL statement result is returned as a {@link CuramValueList} populated with the results of the dynamic data access SQL as a list of details objects, the type of which are specified as an input parameter. This method does not commit any changes on to the database. The SQL should take the same form as handcrafted SQL in the model. For example: SELECT attribute_one, attribute_two INTO :attribute_one,:attribute_two FROM DynamicSQLTestEnt WHERE attribute_one=:attribute_one; The method requires the type of the objects contained in the list to be defined. The class of the argument that will be passed to make up the SQL statement should also be defined, along with a boolean indicator detailing if auditing should be performed for the SQL statement, and the handcrafted SQL string. @param Details Struct Type @param dtlsClass The type of the objects to be contained in the returned list. @param key The class of the argument that will be passed to make up the dynamicSQL statement. null should be passed in if a key is not to be used. @param performAuditing Whether the database updates done by this operation should be recorded on an audit trail. @param dynamicSQL A valid SQL statement to be executed against the database. @return The {@link CuramValueList} populated with the results of the dynamic data access SQL as a list of details objects, the type of which are specified as an input parameter. The list contains all the entries and not only the curam.db.readmultimax number of records. If the readmulti maximum is reached then a readmulti-max message gets logged. @throws AppException If the provided dynamicSQL is not syntactically correct. @throws InformationalException Generic exception signature. @throws OtherDatabaseException If the provided dynamicSQL throws any database exception.

This class provides support for application tests. It builds a repository of the key information used when inserting into entities. This can be used during test execution to validate behavior.
@author PS

Obtain the first field of the entity key, if that field is of type long. You can examine the hasUniqueId flag to check if the unique id value has been set after a given insert.
@return The first field of the entity key.

method.name: hasUniqueID

class.doc: Class containing key information from the most recently insert instance of an application entity. You can look up the most recent instance via the KeyRepository class. There is only one instance (the most recent) per entity, so once you have a reference to the EntityKeyInfo for an entity, you do not need to look it up again -- the values in the instance you hold will change after inserts on the named entity.

method.name: filter
first
operation
post
pre
getMaximum
method.doc:
Provides the maximum number of rows that should be returned by a readmulti operation. 0 is a special case meaning all rows should be returned. If more rows are present than the maximum a {@link curam.util.exception.ReadmultiMaxException ReadmultiMaxException} is thrown by the data access code.
@return The maximum number of rows that should be returned by a readmulti operation. The default is zero.

method.name: requireInformational
method.doc:
Returns whether the informationalRequired parameter has been set in the constructor of this Operation.
@return Boolean indicating if the informationalRequired parameter has been set.

method.name: onMaximumReached

class.doc:
A Curam "readmulti" operation is one which retrieves multiple rows from the application database. Each entity's readmulti operations comes in two forms - the simplest of these returns all of the target database rows as a vector in memory. The second form takes an instance of ReadmultiOperation which is called for each of the rows in the target result set. This allows developers to produce there own custom processing for result sets, without ever having to assemble the entire result set in memory at one time.

When subclassing ReadmultiOperation, you must provide an implementation of the "operation" method, which is called for each row in the result set. All other methods are optional. @author Peter Swords @param the type of the row in the result set

method.name: dpHandleError
method.doc:
Gives application developers control over error handling when the invocation of a deferred process fails. This callback is invoked once the deferred processing message has been moved to the DPError queue (usually after the failing process has been retried several times).

@param processName The name of the deferred process that failed. @param instanceDataID The unique identifier of the InstanceData table record associated with the deferred process that has failed. @throws AppException Since this is a callback method, implemented by application developers, it is possible that the application-defined logic may throw an exception. If this occurs, the DP engine will log the error and retry the processing. If the retries do not succeed, the deferred process is halted. @throws InformationalException Generic Exception Signature.

See the Curam Workflow Management System Developers Guide for more details. @author IQ

interface.name: EventFilter

method.name: accept

interface.doc:
This class defines an interface for filtering events raised by the Curam event service. The event service allows application code to respond to events raised by other parts of the application by implementing an event handler. Event handlers listen for events based on the event class. However some handlers may only be in subset of events of the specified type. An event filter can be implemented to determine which events to forward to the associated event handler and which events to ignore. See {@link curam.util.events.impl.EventHandler EventHandler} for a more detailed description of an event handler. Every filter must also be registered with the event service before it can be used.

An event is passed as the parameter to the {@link curam.util.events.impl.EventFilter#accept accept} method. See {@link curam.util.events.impl.EventService EventService} for a more detailed description of an event.

Event filter processing is implementation-specific but there are a few issues with the Curam event filtering mechanism which may influence the implementation:

  • Every event filter implementation is explicitly associated with an event class. The scope of the event class type can be as specialized or generalized as the implementation requires. There are no restrictions on the number of filters and/or event class types. No default event filter is provided with the event service.

    @author FG

interface.name: EventHandler

method.name: eventRaised

interface.doc:
This class defines an interface for processing events created by the Curam event service. The event service allows application code to respond to events raised by other parts of the application by implementing an event handler. Event handlers listen for events based on the event class.

An event handler allows application logic to be developed that is triggered as a result of some event occurring in the application. This means additional logic can be added to any application logic that raises an event by implementing an event handler and registering it as a listener for the relevant event class. Every handler must also be registered with the event service before it can be used. An event handler may have an associated event filter which determines whether that handler should be invoked for that event. See {@link curam.util.events.impl.EventFilter EventFilter} for a more detailed description of an event filter.

An event is passed as the parameter to the {@link curam.util.events.impl.EventHandler#eventRaised eventRaised} method. See {@link curam.util.events.impl.EventService EventService} for a more detailed description of an event.

Event handler processing is implementation-specific but there are a few issues with the Curam event handling mechanism which may influence the implementation:

  • The underlying event handling mechanism uses the event class to trigger the invocation of the required event handler. Every handler should be considered as single-pass-per-event. Events that are read but for which no handler has been invoked are discarded.

  • Every event handler implementation is explicitly associated with an event class. The scope of the event class can be as specialized or generalized as the implementation requires. There are no restrictions on the number of handlers and/or event classes. No default event handler is provided with the event service.

  • For every event class, there can be multiple associated events. An event is defined as a combination of event class, event type and event data. Again, the scope of the event classes and event types are implementation specific and there are no restrictions on the number of event types associated with an event class.

    @author ST

class.name: EventService

method.name: raiseEvent

class.doc:
EventService is an API for creating events that drive the Curam event infrastructure.

This class enables an application to make use of the observer pattern, where one area of the application (the observer) can register interest in an event raised by another area of the application (the observed). It can therefore be used in situations where an application requires a means of associating otherwise independent activities. The link between the two is an event handler. An event handler interface provides an implementation space for a user-defined handler. See {@link curam.util.events.impl.EventHandler EventHandler} for more details. Event filters can be associated with the event handler to determine whether or not the handler is invoked. See {@link curam.util.events.impl.EventFilter EventFilter} for more details.

When an event is raised, the event service checks to see if there is a filter registered for the event class. If an event filter is registered for the event and if the filter determines that an event handler should be invoked, the event service checks to see if there is a handler registered for the event class. If there is, the event handler is invoked to process the event.

The basic mechanism of event handling is as follows: the application raises an event of a particular class. The event service invokes the event filter and event handler for that event class. This assumes the event class has been registered against the appropriate filter and handler and that the event match engine is aware of both the filter and the handler through the relevant application properties. An event contains 

 
  •  an event class - a named functional area of an application, e.g.
 Case.
 
  •  an event type - a named source of events associated with a biz object
 type, e.g. CaseOpen.
 
  •  event match data - this can be any numeric value relevant to the
 process of event matching, e.g. Case ID.
 
  •  event output mapping data - this can be any numeric value and is
 intended for events that must represent an association between two entities.
 
  •  the raised by user - the name of the user that raised the event.

    • The event class is by convention in Curam a functional area of an application with one or more event types defined as event sources. For example, an event class of "Case" might be associated with three different event types: SubmitCase, CloseCase, OpenCase. Each event class/event type pairing: Case/SubmitCase, Case/CloseCase, Case/OpenCase plus the corresponding event data define an event.

    @author ST

class.doc:
AppException is commonly thrown in Curam applications to indicate a condition that the calling code might wish to handle. In general, all checked Curam exceptions are instances of AppException. Every business object method declaration includes AppException in its "throws" clause.

You catch AppExceptions when you want to add some context-specific information by throwing your own exception instance. As a rule of thumb, if you are not adding any more specific information, don't bother catching the exception . If you are catching an exception, but don't wish to lose stack trace and other information about the exception, you can chain the caught exception on to the new one that you create and throw.

AppExceptions have message text associated with them. Rather than specifying the text directly when you instantiate AppException, a reference to an entry in a message catalog is used. The reference is a constant value generated by Curam based on message catalog definitions in a ".msg" file. {@link curam.util.message.MessageCatalog Message Catalogs} allow messages to be localized. The message text can also have "placeholders" associated with it, replaced at runtime with arguments that you add to the exception.

Placeholders can appear anywhere in the message text and are introduced by a percent character e.g.: "This is the text of message number %1n"

Placeholders are of the form: `%nc`, where n is a number (of 1 or more digits), and c is a single character denoting the argument type as follows:

  • s - string
  • n - numeric
  • d - date
  • t - time
  • z - date/time
  • c - code item
The `\` character can be used as an escape character anywhere in the message text, and must be used whenever the message text needs to contain a percent sign `\%`, or a backslash `\\`.

The code item is treated separately from a string to allow for localization in the client. Code Items are returned in the text of an exception as <TableName>:<Code>. This ensures that the client can present the associated description in the correct language for the user.

In your code, you provide arguments to replace placeholders with the "arg" methods of AppException. Here's an example: AppException e = new AppException(MY_CATALOG.MYEXCEPTION); e.arg("some text"); e.arg(25); throw e; Because the "arg" methods return a reference to the AppException, the above is equivalent to the following shorthand:

throw (new AppException(MY_CATALOG.MYEXCEPTION)).arg("some text"). arg(25);

The order in which you add arguments determines which placeholders they replace -- the first argument replaces the placeholder with number 1, the second replaces number 2, and so on. This means that localized versions of messages can have placeholders which do not appear in the same order as the non-localized ones.

It should be noted that if a string is provided as an argument where a code table is specified then the string will be output. If a code table is used as an argument where a string is specified then the code table will be output. @see AppRuntimeException @author PS

class.doc:
An unchecked exception that can be thrown by various Curam infrastructure facilities. Various facilities, especially those involving accesses to the application database may throw unchecked exceptions. It would be unwieldy for application code to have to explicitly handle all such exceptions. Therefore, {@link AppRuntimeException AppRuntimeException} and its various subclasses should be handled when it can be reasonably expected that such an exception could occur, e.g.: 
 try {
   myEntityObject.read(myKey);
 } catch (curam.util.exception.RecordNotFoundException e) {
   // handle it here
 }
Usually, an {@link AppException AppException} is caught, and an appropriate context-specific {@link AppException AppException} is constructed and thrown in response. Using exception chaining, the {@link AppRuntimeException AppRuntimeException} can be tagged onto the end of the {@link AppException AppException} if this is appropriate.

A failure to handle an {@link AppRuntimeException AppRuntimeException} will result in it being caught by a "last-chance" exception handler and logged to a central log file. {@link AppRuntimeException AppRuntimeException} is implemented as a wrapper around an {@link AppException AppException}, so it has the same message text and other functionality as {@link AppException AppException}. @author PS

class.doc: Unchecked exception thrown by data access code. You do not normally instantiate this exception yourself. Subclasses of this exception (such as {@link RecordNotFoundException RecordNotFoundException}, {@link DuplicateRecordException DuplicateRecordException}, etc.) may be thrown by data access routines and handled by application code. If such an exception is not handled `Curam's` last-chance handlers will log the exception along with meta data describing the data access that caused it to occur. @see AppRuntimeException @author PS

Conversion exception thrown when constructing {@link curam.util.type.Date Dates} and {@link curam.util.type.DateTime DateTimes}. This exception is not intended to be constructed directly by application code.

class.name: DuplicateRecordException
class.doc:
Unchecked exception thrown by data access code when a database record insert would result in a duplicate value in a unique column. You do not normally instantiate this exception yourself and if it is not explicitly handled `Curam's` last-chance handlers will log the exception along with meta data describing the data access that caused it to occur.
@author Peter Swords

class.doc:
LocalisableString is commonly used in Curam applications to produce a string which can be localized by the client. This is similar in construction and use to the AppException class - but a LocalisableString cannot be thrown.

LocalisableString objects have message text associated with them. Rather than specifying the text directly when you instantiate the class, a reference to an entry in a message catalog is used. The reference is a constant value generated by Curam based on message catalog definitions in a ".xml" file. {@link curam.util.message.MessageCatalog Message Catalogs} allow messages to be localized. The message text can also have "placeholders" associated with it, replaced at runtime with arguments that you add to the exception.

Placeholders can appear anywhere in the message text and are introduced by a percent character e.g.: "This is the text of message number %1n"

Placeholders are of the form: `%nc`, where n is a number (of 1 or more digits), and c is a single character denoting the argument type as follows:

  • s - string
  • n - numeric
  • d - date
  • t - time
  • z - date/time
  • c - code item
The `'\'` character can be used as an escape character anywhere in the message text, and must be used whenever the message text needs to contain a percent sign `'\%'`, or a backslash `'\\'`.

The code item is treated separately from a string to allow for localization in the client. Code Items are returned in the text of an exception as <TableName>:<Code>. This ensures that the client can present the associated description in the correct language for the user.

In your code, you provide arguments to replace placeholders with the "arg" methods of LocalisableString. Here's an example: LocalisableString ls = new LocalisableString(MY_CATALOG.MYMESSAGE); ls.arg("some text"); ls.arg(25); Because the "arg" methods return a reference to the LocalisableString, the above is equivalent to the following shorthand: new LocalisableString(MY_CATALOG.MYMESSAGE).arg("some text") .arg(25); The order in which you add arguments determines which placeholders they replace -- the first argument replaces the placeholder with number 1, the second replaces number 2, and so on. This means that localized versions of messages can have placeholders which do not appear in the same order as the non-localized ones.

It should be noted that if a string is provided as an argument where a code table is specified then the string will be output. If a code table is used as an argument where a string is specified then the code table will be output. @see AppException @author DM

class.name: MultipleRecordException
class.doc:
Unchecked exception thrown by data access code when a read operation which was expected to be a singleton operation retrieves multiple records. This is not expected to be constructed by handcrafted code.
@author Peter Swords

class.name: OtherDatabaseException
class.doc:
Unchecked exception thrown by data access code when a database operation results in an error which is not otherwise special-cased by the Curam infrastructure. See the exceptions in the curam.util.exception package for exceptions which are special-cased.

OtherDatabaseException is always thrown in response to a {@link java.sql.SQLException SQLException} generated by a database manager. The error text associated with the underlying exception is incorporated into the text of the OtherDatabaseException. This is not expected to be constructed by handcrafted code. @author Peter Swords

class.name: OverflowException
class.doc:
Unchecked exception thrown by data access code when a database record insert or modify request contains a field that is too large for it's corresponding database column. This is not expected to be constructed by handcrafted code.
@author DM

class.name: ReadmultiMaxException
class.doc:
ReadmultiMaxException is an unchecked exception thrown by Data Access Layer code when a multiple read retrieves more records than the maximum specified in the application model. This is not expected to be constructed by handcrafted code.
@author Peter Swords

class.name: RecordChangedException
class.doc:
Unchecked exception thrown when an optimistic update fails because the target record has changed.

In Curam, optimistic updates are based on a version numbering scheme. The application code reads a record from the database, and notes the version number contained there. When the record needs to be updated it is re-read and locked for update. The application supplies the originally read version number to the update operation. If the original and current version numbers match, then the version number is incremented and the target record is updated. If the original and current version numbers do not match, this implies that another application process has updated the target record since it was originally read. In order to avoid overwriting the updated record contents a RecordChangedException is thrown. Typically this is a rare occurrence, but recovery usually entails redoing the current transaction. This is not expected to be constructed from handcrafted code. @see RecordDeletedException @author Peter Swords

class.name: RecordDeletedException
class.doc:
Unchecked exception thrown when an optimistic update fails because the target record has been deleted.

In Curam, optimistic updates are based on a version numbering scheme. The application code reads a record from the database, and notes the version number contained there. When the record needs to be updated it is re-read and locked for update. If the target record does not exist at this point it implies that another application process has deleted the target record since it was originally read, and a RecordDeletedException is thrown. Typically this is a rare occurrence, but recovery usually entails redoing the current transaction. This is not expected to be thrown from hand-crafted code. @see RecordChangedException @author Peter Swords

class.name: RecordLockedException
RecordNotFoundException
SvrRemoteException

method.name: getExceptionDetails
method.doc:
Obtain the string array containing the exception details. Each entry in the array reflects a different exception.
@return The exception details for each of the exceptions. null is returned if there are no exceptions.

method.name: toString
method.doc:
Obtain a single string containing the exception stored in the localisedException attribute. This interface would typically be used by a web service client. The locale of the exception message is the default locale used on the server and return value contains the reconstituted exception message as originally created on the server. The type, field name, message catalog and message identifier information is discarded from this string. Multi-message exceptions are not supported through this interface.
@return The message of the exception passed in through the constructor or null if the attribute is empty.
